Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[ ♪ Intro ♪ ] It’s that time again! I’m getting a haircut later today. lots of people get them   Sometimes people decide to cut their hair
much shorter, and sometimes they just get a trim, like I am. Even Squeaks had a little trim when he got
a piece of gum stuck his fur, remember, Squeaks? [Squeaks squeaks] But there’s something that all haircuts
have in common: They don’t hurt! When you think about it, it might seem kind
of weird that they don’t. I mean, if you get a cut on almost any other
part of your body, like your finger, it definitely hurts! But when someone cuts your hair, as long as
you hold very still, it doesn’t hurt at all! There’s also another place on our bodies
that it doesn’t hurt to cut, and we do it all the time. Can you guess what it is, Squeaks? [Squeaks guesses] That’s right — our nails! The reason it doesn’t hurt to cut your hair,
toenails, or fingernails is that they don’t have nerves inside them. A nerve is a type of body part you have all
over the inside of your body, kind of like how you have muscles all over. These nerves have a special job to do: they
carry messages between different places in your body. Now, you have lots of body parts. So nerves have lots of jobs. But one of the biggest jobs nerves have is
to help you sense the world around you. Nerves are the reason you can see, hear, smell,
taste … and yes, feel things! Nerves are a big part of the sense of touch. Squeaks, can I touch your nose to show how
this works? [Squeaks squeaks] When you touch something [taps Squeaks on
the nose], it brushes up against your skin. And, like most parts of your body, your skin
has nerves in it. When something touches your skin, it activates,
or kind of ‘turns on’ the nerves. These nerves can feel all kinds of different
things. Some of them feel whether something is warm
or cold. Others can help us tell if something is smooth
or rough. And there are also some that are in charge
of sensing pain. When I tap Squeaks’ nose, some of the nerves
in my finger get switched on, and each one sends a message. Those messages travel through my hands … up
my arm … through a big bundle of nerves that’s in my back … and all the way to
my brain! Then, my brain decodes the messages. It checks if I’ve ever touched anything
like this before, and combines that with any other information it can get, like if I can
see the thing I’m feeling. This all happens really fast, which is how
I can figure out what I’m touching right away — Squeaks’ nose! [Squeaks sneezes] Oh, I’m sorry ! I guess your nose is kinda
ticklish, Squeaks! So, our sense of touch takes more than just
our hands. It also takes our nerves, and our brains,
too! But what about our hair? Well, try this. Pat the top of your head. Just like the skin that’s on your fingers,
the skin that’s under your hair has nerves. So your fingers can feel the top of your head,
and your head can feel your fingers touching it! Just like how Squeaks felt my finger with
his nose. Now find the very end of a piece of hair and
try squeezing it, without pulling on it at all. Your fingers can feel your hair, but your
hair can’t feel your fingers! That’s because there are no nerves inside
your hair. And as long as you’re not pulling on your
hair, or moving it around too much, you’re not going to feel a thing. The same goes for the very ends of your fingernails
and toenails. They don’t have nerves in them either. No nerves means no sense of touch, so they
don’t feel anything. And if there’s no sense of touch, there’s
no pain. So the next time you get a haircut, now you’ll
know why it doesn’t hurt! [Squeaks squeaks] Yikes, you’re right Squeaks — I should
go if I don’t want to be late for my haircut! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! [♪ Outro ♪ ]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the brain receives a message from the nerves, it decodes the message. What does this mean?
Options: A. The brain receives the message, checks to see if it is a good message or a bad message, decides what steps to take, and then sends the action step back., B. The brain receives the message, checks to see if it feels like the correct message, decides which steps to take next, and then combines it with other messages it is receiving., C. The brain receives the message, checks to see if they have ever sensed something like the message they are receiving before, and combines that with any other information it can get. (If I touch something ,can I also see it), D. The brain receives the message, checks to see if they truly sense it or if it is a false positive, combines that decision with other information and returns a message.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Why doesn't it hurt when you get a haircut? Options: A. Because haircuts are done by professionals., B. Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because haircuts are done with special scissors., D. Because hair is not a part of the body. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main job of nerves in the body? Options: A. To carry messages between different places in the body., B. To move muscles and bones., C. To digest food in the stomach., D. To breathe air in and out of the lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the sense that nerves help us with, which allows us to feel things? Options: A. Sight, B. Hearing, C. Smell, D. Touch Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens when something touches our skin? Options: A. It activates our muscles., B. It activates our nerves., C. It activates our brain., D. It activates our senses. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Where do the messages from our nerves travel to? Options: A. To our muscles., B. To our brain., C. To our heart., D. To our lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the brain's role in our sense of touch? Options: A. To send messages to our nerves., B. To decode the messages from our nerves., C. To move our muscles., D. To breathe air in and out of the lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why can't our hair feel our fingers when we touch it? Options: A. Because our hair is too thin., B. Because our hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because our fingers are too rough., D. Because our hair is too long. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is another part of our body that doesn't have nerves inside it, like our hair? Options: A. Our skin., B. Our muscles., C. Our fingernails and toenails., D. Our brain. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why doesn't it hurt when we cut our fingernails or toenails? Options: A. Because we use special scissors., B. Because our fingernails and toenails don't have nerves inside them., C. Because we cut them carefully., D. Because they are not a part of the body. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main reason why we don't feel pain when we get a haircut? Options: A. Because haircuts are done by professionals., B. Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because haircuts are done with special scissors., D. Because our brain doesn't send pain signals. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 6: What is the brain's role in our sense of touch? Options: A. To send messages to our nerves., B. To decode the messages from our nerves., C. To move our muscles., D. To breathe air in and out of the lungs.**

This generated MCQ is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ because it:

1. Deals with the brain's role in processing information from the nerves.
2. Mentions decoding messages from the nerves, which is similar to the ground truth MCQ's description of the brain decoding messages.
3. Has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which is to understand how the brain processes information from the nerves.

However, it's worth noting that the options in the generated MCQ are not as detailed or accurate as the options in the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, based on the available options, I would say that Question 6 is the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **6**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2

[ ♪ Intro ♪ ] It’s that time again! I’m getting a haircut later today. lots of people get them   Sometimes people decide to cut their hair
much shorter, and sometimes they just get a trim, like I am. Even Squeaks had a little trim when he got

don’t feel anything. And if there’s no sense of touch, there’s
no pain. So the next time you get a haircut, now you’ll
know why it doesn’t hurt! [Squeaks squeaks] Yikes, you’re right Squeaks — I should
go if I don’t want to be late for my haircut! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! [♪ Outro ♪ ]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a nerve?
Options: A. A body part that lives at the ends of our fingers and toes., B. A body part that runs all over the inside of your body., C. A body part that lives in our brains., D. A body part that lives in our hearts.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Why doesn't it hurt when you get a haircut? Options: A. Because haircuts are done by professionals., B. Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because haircuts are done with special scissors., D. Because hair is not a part of the body. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main job of nerves in the body? Options: A. To carry messages between different places in the body., B. To move muscles and bones., C. To digest food in the stomach., D. To breathe air in and out of the lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the sense that nerves help us with, which allows us to feel things? Options: A. Sight, B. Hearing, C. Smell, D. Touch Correct Option: None
Question 4: What happens when something touches our skin? Options: A. It activates our muscles., B. It activates our nerves., C. It activates our brain., D. It activates our senses. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Where do the messages from our nerves travel to? Options: A. To our muscles., B. To our brain., C. To our heart., D. To our lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the brain's role in our sense of touch? Options: A. To send messages to our nerves., B. To decode the messages from our nerves., C. To move our muscles., D. To breathe air in and out of the lungs. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why can't our hair feel our fingers when we touch it? Options: A. Because our hair is too thin., B. Because our hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because our fingers are too rough., D. Because our hair is too long. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is another part of our body that doesn't have nerves inside it, like our hair? Options: A. Our skin., B. Our muscles., C. Our fingernails and toenails., D. Our brain. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why doesn't it hurt when we cut our fingernails or toenails? Options: A. Because we use special scissors., B. Because our fingernails and toenails don't have nerves inside them., C. Because we cut them carefully., D. Because they are not a part of the body. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main reason why we don't feel pain when we get a haircut? Options: A. Because haircuts are done by professionals., B. Because hair doesn't have nerves inside it., C. Because haircuts are done with special scissors., D. Because our brain doesn't send pain signals. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[ ♪ Intro ♪ ] It’s that time again! I’m getting a haircut later today. lots of people get them   Sometimes people decide to cut their hair
much shorter, and sometimes they just get a trim, like I am. Even Squeaks had a little trim when he got
a piece of gum stuck his fur, remember, Squeaks? [Squeaks squeaks] But there’s something that all haircuts
have in common: They don’t hurt! When you think about it, it might seem kind
of weird that they don’t. I mean, if you get a cut on almost any other
part of your body, like your finger, it definitely hurts! But when someone cuts your hair, as long as
you hold very still, it doesn’t hurt at all! There’s also another place on our bodies
that it doesn’t hurt to cut, and we do it all the time. Can you guess what it is, Squeaks? [Squeaks guesses] That’s right — our nails! The reason it doesn’t hurt to cut your hair,
toenails, or fingernails is that they don’t have nerves inside them. A nerve is a type of body part you have all
over the inside of your body, kind of like how you have muscles all over. These nerves have a special job to do: they
carry messages between different places in your body. Now, you have lots of body parts. So nerves have lots of jobs. But one of the biggest jobs nerves have is
to help you sense the world around you. Nerves are the reason you can see, hear, smell,
taste … and yes, feel things! Nerves are a big part of the sense of touch. Squeaks, can I touch your nose to show how
this works? [Squeaks squeaks] When you touch something [taps Squeaks on
the nose], it brushes up against your skin. And, like most parts of your body, your skin
has nerves in it. When something touches your skin, it activates,
or kind of ‘turns on’ the nerves. These nerves can feel all kinds of different
things. Some of them feel whether something is warm
or cold. Others can help us tell if something is smooth
or rough. And there are also some that are in charge
of sensing pain. When I tap Squeaks’ nose, some of the nerves
in my finger get switched on, and each one sends a message. Those messages travel through my hands … up
my arm … through a big bundle of nerves that’s in my back … and all the way to
my brain! Then, my brain decodes the messages. It checks if I’ve ever touched anything
like this before, and combines that with any other information it can get, like if I can
see the thing I’m feeling. This all happens really fast, which is how
I can figure out what I’m touching right away — Squeaks’ nose! [Squeaks sneezes] Oh, I’m sorry ! I guess your nose is kinda
ticklish, Squeaks! So, our sense of touch takes more than just
our hands. It also takes our nerves, and our brains,
too! But what about our hair? Well, try this. Pat the top of your head. Just like the skin that’s on your fingers,
the skin that’s under your hair has nerves. So your fingers can feel the top of your head,
and your head can feel your fingers touching it! Just like how Squeaks felt my finger with
his nose. Now find the very end of a piece of hair and
try squeezing it, without pulling on it at all. Your fingers can feel your hair, but your
hair can’t feel your fingers! That’s because there are no nerves inside
your hair. And as long as you’re not pulling on your
hair, or moving it around too much, you’re not going to feel a thing. The same goes for the very ends of your fingernails
and toenails. They don’t have nerves in them either. No nerves means no sense of touch, so they
don’t feel anything. And if there’s no sense of touch, there’s
no pain. So the next time you get a haircut, now you’ll
know why it doesn’t hurt! [Squeaks squeaks] Yikes, you’re right Squeaks — I should
go if I don’t want to be late for my haircut! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! [♪ Outro ♪ ]

Question: What is the nerve's main job?
Options: A. The main job is to warn you of what will happen next., B. The main job is to carry messages., C. The main job is to let you know when something happens., D. The main job is to sense the world around you.
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
♪INTRO♪ Hey, Squeaks... (Squeaks squeaks) Oh, I'm ok. My leg just feels kinda weird... It’s tingling, but in a way that feels prickly! [Squeaks Squeaks] Oh yeah, you're right! I think my leg is asleep! Maybe this has happened to you before, too. Sometimes if you’ve been doing something
that presses on your arms or legs for a while, like sitting in one position or leaning on
your elbow, it’ll start to go numb and you can’t feel as much with that part of your
body. Then, once you move so you’re not sitting
or leaning that way anymore, your arm or leg starts to get all prickly, almost like you’re
getting lots of tiny pokes all over, even though there’s nothing actually poking you. People sometimes call that feeling pins and
needles. And that sounds a lot like what happened to
me! It’s something that can feel pretty weird,
even though it happens to people all the time. When we say that an arm or leg fell asleep,
we don’t really mean that it was asleep the way you are when you fall asleep at night. It’s just called that because you can’t
feel much with it while it’s numb, almost like it’s sleeping. And that tingling, pins and needles feeling
you get when you shift your position is kind of like your arm or leg is waking up! You get that prickly feeling because your
body is a little bit confused. You might already know that there’s blood
moving everywhere in your body all the time, pumped through little tubes called blood vessels
by your heart. It’s really important that the blood moves
through all the parts of your body, because that’s how they get energy so they can work
properly. But when you sit in one position or lean on
your arm or leg for a while, you’re pressing on those blood vessels and making the tubes
smaller, so not as much blood can get through. And without enough blood, your arm or leg
can start to go numb. The reason you can feel something when you
touch it is because of little things called nerves that are all over your body. Whenever you pick up a toy or touch something
that’s hot or cold or hurts, these nerves are like little messengers that tell your
brain all about what you’re touching. But the nerves only work well if they’re
getting enough blood. I must have sat in a way that was pressing
on his leg for a few minutes, the nerves in my leg weren’t getting enough blood. So my leg stopped being able to feel as much
— it went numb and fell asleep. But then I moved! And once my body wasn’t pressing on his
leg anymore, more blood started moving through it again and his nerves woke up. But nerves get a liiiittle confused when they
wake up. At first, they don’t really know /what/
you’re feeling. They start telling your brain that you’re
feeling tiny little pokes, even though nothing is really touching you! That’s where the pins and needles feeling
comes from. Pretty soon, your nerves get used to having
enough blood again and go right back to normal. So to keep yourself from getting pins and
needles, you can just make sure you don’t sit or lean in one position for too long. And if you do get them, all you have to do
is just wait. You can shake around the arm or leg in the
meantime to help the blood get flowing again, but either way, the prickling will go away
after a minute or two. Whew, Squeaks! It feels like my nerves are finally getting
back to normal! My leg is better now! But now the next time I get pins and needles,
I’ll know all about why it happens. And so will you! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! ♪Outro♪

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What do we call that sharp, poking feeling after you move a leg or arm that has fallen asleep?
Options: A. Pins and Needles, B. Pins and Sledgehammers, C. Needles and Nails, D. Pokers and Pins
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the tingling, prickly feeling in your arm or leg called when it has been numb and then starts to get feeling back? Options: A. Pins and Sticks, B. Numbness and Pain, C. Pins and Needles, D. Tingling and Itching Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why do people say that an arm or leg "fell asleep" when it becomes numb? Options: A. Because it is actually sleeping like the rest of the body at night., B. Because it is numb and can't feel much, like it is sleeping., C. Because it is a medical term for numbness., D. Because it is a type of injury. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the blood vessels when you sit in one position or lean on your arm or leg for a while? Options: A. They get bigger and more blood flows through., B. They stay the same size and the same amount of blood flows through., C. They get smaller and less blood flows through., D. They disappear and no blood flows through. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why do nerves need blood to work properly? Options: A. So they can move around the body., B. So they can send signals to the brain., C. So they can feel sensations like touch and temperature., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the nerves when they don't get enough blood? Options: A. They start to work better., B. They stay the same., C. They stop working and the area becomes numb., D. They start to hurt. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why do nerves get confused when they start getting blood again after being numb? Options: A. Because they are damaged., B. Because they are tired., C. Because they need time to adjust to the new blood flow., D. Because they are sending wrong signals to the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What can you do to help get rid of the pins and needles feeling? Options: A. Shake the affected arm or leg., B. Rub the affected arm or leg., C. Wait for a minute or two., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How can you prevent getting pins and needles? Options: A. By sitting in one position for a long time., B. By leaning on your arm or leg for a long time., C. By moving around regularly and not sitting or leaning in one position for too long., D. By taking medication. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the role of nerves in the body? Options: A. To move the body around., B. To send signals to the brain about sensations like touch and temperature., C. To pump blood throughout the body., D. To breathe. Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important for blood to flow through all parts of the body? Options: A. So the body can move around., B. So the body can feel sensations like touch and temperature., C. So the body can get energy and work properly., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the wording of the question is slightly different, the intent and content of the question are the same as the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 1 is also "Pins and Needles" (Option C), which matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What part of the circulatory system is affected when we have a leg or arm fall asleep?
Options: A. Heart, B. Blood Vessels, C. Capillaries, D. Muscles
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the tingling, prickly feeling in your arm or leg called when it has been numb and then starts to get feeling back? Options: A. Pins and Sticks, B. Numbness and Pain, C. Pins and Needles, D. Tingling and Itching Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why do people say that an arm or leg "fell asleep" when it becomes numb? Options: A. Because it is actually sleeping like the rest of the body at night., B. Because it is numb and can't feel much, like it is sleeping., C. Because it is a medical term for numbness., D. Because it is a type of injury. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the blood vessels when you sit in one position or lean on your arm or leg for a while? Options: A. They get bigger and more blood flows through., B. They stay the same size and the same amount of blood flows through., C. They get smaller and less blood flows through., D. They disappear and no blood flows through. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why do nerves need blood to work properly? Options: A. So they can move around the body., B. So they can send signals to the brain., C. So they can feel sensations like touch and temperature., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the nerves when they don't get enough blood? Options: A. They start to work better., B. They stay the same., C. They stop working and the area becomes numb., D. They start to hurt. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why do nerves get confused when they start getting blood again after being numb? Options: A. Because they are damaged., B. Because they are tired., C. Because they need time to adjust to the new blood flow., D. Because they are sending wrong signals to the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What can you do to help get rid of the pins and needles feeling? Options: A. Shake the affected arm or leg., B. Rub the affected arm or leg., C. Wait for a minute or two., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How can you prevent getting pins and needles? Options: A. By sitting in one position for a long time., B. By leaning on your arm or leg for a long time., C. By moving around regularly and not sitting or leaning in one position for too long., D. By taking medication. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the role of nerves in the body? Options: A. To move the body around., B. To send signals to the brain about sensations like touch and temperature., C. To pump blood throughout the body., D. To breathe. Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important for blood to flow through all parts of the body? Options: A. So the body can move around., B. So the body can feel sensations like touch and temperature., C. So the body can get energy and work properly., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
♪INTRO♪ Hey, Squeaks... (Squeaks squeaks) Oh, I'm ok. My leg just feels kinda weird... It’s tingling, but in a way that feels prickly! [Squeaks Squeaks] Oh yeah, you're right! I think my leg is asleep! Maybe this has happened to you before, too. Sometimes if you’ve been doing something
that presses on your arms or legs for a while, like sitting in one position or leaning on
your elbow, it’ll start to go numb and you can’t feel as much with that part of your
body. Then, once you move so you’re not sitting
or leaning that way anymore, your arm or leg starts to get all prickly, almost like you’re
getting lots of tiny pokes all over, even though there’s nothing actually poking you. People sometimes call that feeling pins and
needles. And that sounds a lot like what happened to
me! It’s something that can feel pretty weird,
even though it happens to people all the time. When we say that an arm or leg fell asleep,
we don’t really mean that it was asleep the way you are when you fall asleep at night. It’s just called that because you can’t
feel much with it while it’s numb, almost like it’s sleeping. And that tingling, pins and needles feeling
you get when you shift your position is kind of like your arm or leg is waking up! You get that prickly feeling because your
body is a little bit confused. You might already know that there’s blood
moving everywhere in your body all the time, pumped through little tubes called blood vessels
by your heart. It’s really important that the blood moves
through all the parts of your body, because that’s how they get energy so they can work
properly. But when you sit in one position or lean on
your arm or leg for a while, you’re pressing on those blood vessels and making the tubes
smaller, so not as much blood can get through. And without enough blood, your arm or leg
can start to go numb. The reason you can feel something when you
touch it is because of little things called nerves that are all over your body. Whenever you pick up a toy or touch something
that’s hot or cold or hurts, these nerves are like little messengers that tell your
brain all about what you’re touching. But the nerves only work well if they’re
getting enough blood. I must have sat in a way that was pressing
on his leg for a few minutes, the nerves in my leg weren’t getting enough blood. So my leg stopped being able to feel as much
— it went numb and fell asleep. But then I moved! And once my body wasn’t pressing on his
leg anymore, more blood started moving through it again and his nerves woke up. But nerves get a liiiittle confused when they
wake up. At first, they don’t really know /what/
you’re feeling. They start telling your brain that you’re
feeling tiny little pokes, even though nothing is really touching you! That’s where the pins and needles feeling
comes from. Pretty soon, your nerves get used to having
enough blood again and go right back to normal. So to keep yourself from getting pins and
needles, you can just make sure you don’t sit or lean in one position for too long. And if you do get them, all you have to do
is just wait. You can shake around the arm or leg in the
meantime to help the blood get flowing again, but either way, the prickling will go away
after a minute or two. Whew, Squeaks! It feels like my nerves are finally getting
back to normal! My leg is better now! But now the next time I get pins and needles,
I’ll know all about why it happens. And so will you! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! ♪Outro♪

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When do the nerves stop sending the sharp, poking feeling?
Options: A. They stop when they feel a person start moving again., B. They stop when they receive a message from the brain telling it to stop., C. They stop when they receive enough blood from the blood vessels., D. They stop when the person shakes their arm/leg.
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the tingling, prickly feeling in your arm or leg called when it has been numb and then starts to get feeling back? Options: A. Pins and Sticks, B. Numbness and Pain, C. Pins and Needles, D. Tingling and Itching Correct Option: None

They stay the same size and the same amount of blood flows through., C. They get smaller and less blood flows through., D. They disappear and no blood flows through. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why do nerves need blood to work properly? Options: A. So they can move around the body., B. So they can send signals to the brain., C. So they can feel sensations like touch and temperature., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the nerves when they don't get enough blood? Options: A. They start to work better., B. They stay the same., C. They stop working and the area becomes numb., D. They start to hurt. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why do nerves get confused when they start getting blood again after being numb? Options: A. Because they are damaged., B. Because they are tired., C. Because they need time to adjust to the new blood flow., D. Because they are sending wrong signals to the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What can you do to help get rid of the pins and needles feeling? Options: A. Shake the affected arm or leg., B. Rub the affected arm or leg., C. Wait for a minute or two., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although Question 5 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, its content and options are the most similar. Question 5 asks what happens to the nerves when they don't get enough blood, and one of the options (C) states that they stop working and the area becomes numb. The ground truth MCQ asks when the nerves stop sending the sharp, poking feeling and the correct answer is when they receive enough blood from the blood vessels.

Question 6 asks why nerves get confused when they start getting blood again after being numb, and one possible answer choice (which is not provided) could be that they stop sending the sharp, poking feeling when they adjust to the new blood flow.

**Transcript**:
welcome to my laboratory i want to show you my new machine the pluralator it makes more than one every word has a body a body can have a tail this tale is special it is called a plural the s tells us there is more than one duck that means i can use my plural later see now there are lots of ducks sometimes the tail that is a plural is e s e s makes the sound is boxes so how do you know when to use s or e s use es after one of these hissing sounds glasses dishes bunches now you know how to use tails to show there is more than one plurals what an excellent student you are so clever oh no the plural later is going out of control stop no i must get out of here it is going crazy

Options: A. More than one, B. A tail, C. It is all alone
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 4: When should you use "es" instead of "s" to form a plural? Options: A. After a vowel sound, B. After a consonant sound, C. After a hissing sound, D. After a silent sound Correct Option: None
Question 5: What are some examples of words that use "es" to form a plural? Options: A. Cats, dogs, and birds, B. Glasses, dishes, and bunches, C. Cars, trucks, and buses, D. Pencils, pens, and papers Correct Option: None

Question 7: What is the result of using the pluralator machine on a single duck? Options: A. The duck disappears, B. The duck gets smaller, C. The duck stays the same, D. There are now lots of ducks Correct Option: None
Question 8: What does the "s" at the end of a word typically indicate? Options: A. That the word is singular, B. That the word is plural, C. That the word is a verb, D. That the word is an adjective Correct Option: None

Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
open the syllable the vowel says its letter name i i i hi closed syllable the vowel makes a short sound hit please don't hit me which of these words are open syllables and which are closed open these are open oh no me closed these are the closed syllables remember when it's closed in the bowel makes a short sound when it is open the vowel says its letter name

Options: A. a short sound, B. its letter name (or a long sound)
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What happens to the vowel sound in an open syllable? Options: A. It makes a short sound., B. It says its letter name., C. It becomes silent., D. It changes to a different vowel sound. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is an example of an open syllable? Options: A. Hit, B. Hi, C. Run, D. Jump Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the vowel sound in a closed syllable? Options: A. It says its letter name., B. It makes a short sound., C. It becomes silent., D. It changes to a different vowel sound. Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable? Options: A. Me, B. No, C. Hit, D. Go Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the rule for vowel sounds in open and closed syllables? Options: A. Open syllables make a short sound, and closed syllables say the letter name., B. Open syllables say the letter name, and closed syllables make a short sound., C. Open syllables become silent, and closed syllables make a short sound., D. Open syllables make a short sound, and closed syllables become silent. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following words are open syllables? Options: A. Hit, Me, B. Hi, No, C. Run, Jump, D. Go, Me Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the difference between an open and a closed syllable? Options: A. An open syllable has one vowel, and a closed syllable has two vowels., B. An open syllable says the letter name, and a closed syllable makes a short sound., C. An open syllable makes a short sound, and a closed syllable says the letter name., D. An open syllable has a consonant at the end, and a closed syllable does not. Correct Option: None
Question 8: Which of the following is a characteristic of a closed syllable? Options: A. The vowel says its letter name., B. The vowel makes a short sound., C. The syllable has two vowels., D. The syllable has a consonant at the beginning. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is an example of a word that is a closed syllable? Options: A. Hi, B. No, C. Hit, D. Go Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main idea of the rule for open and closed syllables? Options: A. Vowels always make a short sound., B. Vowels always say their letter name., C. The position of the vowel determines its sound., D. The number of vowels determines the sound. Correct Option: None

An open syllable says the letter name, and a closed syllable makes a short sound., C. An open syllable makes a short sound, and a closed syllable says the letter name., D. An open syllable has a consonant at the end, and a closed syllable does not. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] welcome to brightly story time i'm miss linda and today's book is special because it's part of a very cool program called read for the record it's a very funny story about a bear and a sandwich it's called the bear ate your sandwich by julia sarcone roach by now i think you know what happened to your sandwich but you may not know how it happened so let me tell you it all started with the bear the morning air was warm and bright when the bear stepped out of his den he stretched and sniffed the scent of ripe berries drifted toward him and led him to a wonderful discovery [Music] a berry feast the bear curled up in the sunlight and listened to the buzzing of the bees before long he was asleep [Music] by the time the bear opened his eyes the buzzing had become a rumbling he was being quickly swept along like a leaf in a great river the forest disappeared in the distance and high cliffs rose up around him [Music] once the rumbling stopped the bear found himself in a new forest it was like nothing he'd ever seen before this forest had many great climbing spots the trees were still itchy here there was good bark for scratching [Music] and the mud squished nicely under his feet there were many interesting smells in this forest but some of the tastiest ones had already been found leafy green smells led the bear to new fun and that is when he saw it [Music] there it was your beautiful and delicious sandwich all alone he waited to make sure no one saw him not even the sandwich before he made his move [Music] it was such a great sandwich the bear loved it but just as he was almost finished he heard sniff snuffle slobber snort behind him he had been seen the bear was so surprised that he ran out of the park and down the street until he spotted a very tall tree from the top of the tree the bear could see his forest it was time to go home the waves rocked the bear and he began to doze [Music] when he opened his eyes he heard the breeze in familiar branches and the birds and bugs evening song well the bear made it home just fine so that's what happened to your sandwich the bear ate it [Music] i saw it all i tried to save your sandwich i was able to save this little bit of lettuce here the bear dropped it as he ran off but i couldn't save the rest i'm sorry to have to tell you about your sandwich this way but now you know [Music] hmm do you believe the dog story about the sandwich i don't know seems suspicious now it's your turn read the bear ager sandwich yourself or find someone to read it to you and you can always find more books at readbrightly.com thank you so much bye [Music] you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: As the bear is traveling in the truck, he describes the change in the sounds he hears. What was the change?
Options: A. The buzzing of the bees becomes the rumbling of car traffic., B. The swooshing of the wind became the rumbling of the cars., C. The rippling of river water becomes the rushing of rapid ocean water., D. The buzzing of bees becomes the noise of technology.
Correct Option: A

Question 3: What happened to the bear while he was asleep? Options: A. He was swept away by a great river, B. He was carried by the bees to a new forest, C. He was woken up by the sound of rumbling, D. He was left alone in the forest Correct Option: None

Question 5: What led the bear to the sandwich? Options: A. The scent of ripe berries, B. The sound of buzzing bees, C. Leafy green smells, D. The sight of the sandwich Correct Option: None

[Music] hmm do you believe the dog story about the sandwich i don't know seems suspicious now it's your turn read the bear ager sandwich yourself or find someone to read it to you and you can always find more books at readbrightly.com thank you so much bye [Music] you

The ground truth MCQ asks about what returned the bear to his forest, with options including a truck, car, boat, and train. The correct answer is a boat, but this information is not explicitly mentioned in the generated MCQs.

However, Question 8: "What did the bear see from the top of the tree?" is the closest match, as it mentions the bear seeing his forest from the top of the tree, which implies that the bear is on his way back to his forest. Although this question does not directly ask about what returned the bear to his forest, it is the closest match in terms of content and intent.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 8.

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 3
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What causes the "hic" sound when a person hiccups?
Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, followed by the vocal folds clamping shut, B. The sudden release of air from the lungs, followed by the diaphragm relaxing, C. The sudden contraction of the vocal folds, followed by the diaphragm contracting, D. The sudden release of air from the throat, followed by the diaphragm relaxing
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What causes the "hic" sound when a person hiccups?
Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, followed by the vocal folds clamping shut, B. The sudden release of air from the lungs, followed by the diaphragm relaxing, C. The sudden contraction of the vocal folds, followed by the diaphragm contracting, D. The sudden release of air from the throat, followed by the diaphragm relaxing
Correct Option: None

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.8000 (The generated question is related to the topic of hiccuping, but it focuses on the specific sound of the hiccup rather than the cause of hiccuping itself.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question does not match the ground truth answer.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.6000 (The distractors in the generated question are somewhat plausible, but they do not perfectly align with the content of the ground truth question.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The generated question and options are clear and easy to understand.)
- Total Score: 0.5750

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 2, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the diaphragm, and what is its function in the human body?
Options: A. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that helps with digestion, B. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing, C. A sheet of muscle in the throat that helps with swallowing, D. A sheet of muscle in the chest that helps with heartbeat regulation
Correct Option: None

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 3, Matched Generated Question 6
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the most common approach to getting rid of hiccups?
Options: A. Stimulating the vagus nerve, B. Increasing carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream, C. Holding your breath for 10 seconds, D. Drinking a glass of water quickly
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the most common approach to getting rid of hiccups?
Options: A. Stimulating the vagus nerve, B. Increasing carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream, C. Holding your breath for 10 seconds, D. Drinking a glass of water quickly
Correct Option: None

**Scores**:

- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question does not match the ground truth answer.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.6000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible but not as effective as they could be. Options C and D are specific techniques rather than general approaches.)

**Transcript**:

people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of

they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp

means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred

of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is one way to get rid of hiccups by stimulating the vagus nerve?
Options: A. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, B. Holding your breath for 10 seconds, C. Drinking a glass of water quickly, D. Breathing into a paper bag
Correct Option: None

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is a potential failure point when building a treehouse?
Options: A. The tree might be too small, B. The treehouse might be too heavy, C. The blankets might not be thick enough, D. The rope ladder might be too short
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.

Question: What is the term used to describe the design of buildings?
Options: A. Engineering, B. Architecture, C. Construction, D. Designing

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What was Malcolm X's famous phrase when speaking against racism?
Options: A. "I have a dream", B. "By any means necessary", C. "We shall overcome", D. "Nonviolent resistance"
Correct Option: None
